head.title: From the Yale Bowl to the Rose Bowl

hedline.hl1: From the Yale Bowl to the Rose Bowl

abstract.p: College football quiz; photos (special section, Education Life) (S)

block.p: 1. Since the first intercollegiate football game in 1869, when Rutgers defeated Princeton, 6-4, there have been many other milestones. Match the event with the year in which it happened:
1. The first Tournament of Roses game (Michigan defeated Stanford, 49-0)
2. A college running back gained more than 2,000 yards in a season (Marcus Allen of the University of Southern California gained 2,342 yards on the ground)
3. The longest field goal in N.C.A.A. history (Both Steve Little of Arkansas and Russell Erxleben of Texas kicked 67-yard field goals)
4. The first woman played college football (Liz Heaston of Willamette University kicked two extra points in a 27-0 victory over Linfield)
5. The first coast-to-coast radio broadcast of a sporting event. (In a broadcast of the Rose Bowl people heard Alabama and Stanford battle to a 7-7 tie)

6. A college football game's outcome was reversed after the game was reviewed on film. (Cornell defeated Dartmouth, but after a film of the game showed that Cornell scored its touchdown on an illegal fifth down, the score was reversed, and Dartmouth was credited with the victory.)
7. The Associated Press began counting Bowl games in the final National Championship ratings
2. Campus colors make these red-letter teams. Match the schools and their teams.
Texas Tech Rutgers Alabama Cornell St. John's Stanford Harvard
Big Red Red Raiders Crimson Scarlet Knights Cardinal Red Storm Crimson Tide
3. The following athletes are among those who have been elected to the College Football Hall of Fame in South Bend, Ind. Match each player with his achievement on the field or off:
1. Jim Thorpe (Carlisle)
2. Byron ''Whizzer'' White (Colorado)
3. Johnny Mack Brown (Alabama)
4. Wear Schoonover (Arkansas)
5. Fritz Pollard (Brown)
6. Alex Karras (Iowa)
7. Hamilton Fish (Harvard)
8. Archie Griffin (Ohio State)
9. Paul Robeson (Rutgers)
10. Bo Jackson (Auburn)
11. Walter Camp (Yale)
a. Became a movie cowboy
b. Played Mongo in ''Blazing Saddles''
c. Was an Olympic Gold medalist
d. Became and internationally acclaimed singer and actor
e. Became a Congressman from New York
f. Was a basketball all-American
g. Is called the father of American football
h. Was the first African-American to play in the Rose Bowl
i. Hit a home run in a Major League Baseball All-Star Game
j. Became a Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
k. Was the only two-time Heisman winner
4. Select the city in which each bowl game is played:
Rose Bowl Pasadena San Diego Los Angeles
Orange Bowl St. Petersburg Miami Orlando
Sun Bowl El Paso Miami Houston
Fiesta Bowl San Antonio Santa Fe Tempe
Sugar Bowl Little Rock New Orleans Birmingham
Cotton Bowl Memphis Dallas Atlanta
Motor City Bowl Pontiac Detroit Indianapolis
Citrus Bowl Miami Key West Orlando
5. Like the trivia categories sports and history? Well, try answering these questions:
1. For which team did the Four Horsemen, the most heralded backfield in football history, play?
2. Which president of the United States threatened to abolish college football by executive edict unless the game was made safer?
3. As a result of his threat, what football play was legalized?
4. Which president of the United States played center on two national championship teams during his college days and later was an assistant football coach at Yale?
5. How long is a football field, how wide, and how high is the crossbar of a goalpost?
6. College football's oldest trophy originated in a game between Michigan and Minnesota in 1909, and the two teams have played for it ever since. What is it called?
6. Identify the movie about college football in which these actors starred:
Brian Dennehy Sean Astin Adam Sandler June Allyson Ronald Reagan Harpo Marx James Caan
''The Water Boy'' ''Knute Rockne, All American'' ''Rudy'' ''Horse Feathers'' ''Good News'' ''Semi-Tough'' ''The Program''
Quiz Answers
The questions are on page 43.
Texas Tech, Red Raiders Rutgers, Scarlet Knights Alabama, Crimson Tide Cornell, Big Red St. John's, Red Storm Stanford, Cardinal Harvard, Crimson
Rose Bowl, Pasadena Orange Bowl, Miami Sun Bowl, El Paso Fiesta Bowl, Tempe Sugar Bowl, New Orleans Cotton Bowl, Dallas Motor City Bowl, Pontiac Citrus Bowl, Orlando

1. Notre Dame. They were: Don Miller, halfback; Elmer Layden, fullback; Jim Crow-ley, halfback and Harry Stuhldreher, quarterback 2. Theodore Roosevelt in 1905 3. The forward pass 4. Gerald Ford, who was the University of Michigan's most valuable player in 1934. 5. 100 yards, 53 1/3yards, 10 feet 6. The ''Little Brown Jug''

Adam Sandler ''The Water Boy'' Ronald Reagan ''Knute Rockne, All American'' Sean Astin ''Rudy'' The Marx Brothers ''Horse Feathers'' June Allyson ''Good News'' Brian Dennehy ''Semi-Tough'' James Caan ''The Program''

QUIZ Correction: August 13, 2000, Sunday The news quiz in the special Education Life section last Sunday misstated the subject of the movie ''Semi-Tough.'' It is professional football, not college football.
Correction: August 13, 2000, Sunday
The news quiz in the special Education Life section last Sunday misstated the subject of the movie ''Semi-Tough.'' It is professional football, not college football.
